documents.title: that 's all for today
text: thanks to tori and sam for taking on your questions .

here 's some parting words from them : guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 3:22pm t : i want to thank everybody for all these amazing questions , and i wish we could have gotten round to all of them .
s : thank you all for listening - hope you like the album .
sarah elizabeth hirsch asks : have you considered revamping songs into a musical .
( kinda like rock of ages , but way cooler ) ?
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:27pm well , right now i 'm more interested in original composition for the theatre or film .
the idea of a jukebox musical is something at present that i would most likely avoid .

mainly because i 'm much more drawn to the possibility of creating something new , whether that 's an adaptation of an existing story , like the light princess , or coming up with something completely new .
we 're looking at the possibilities of the light princess as a film
larissa nash asks : i edit a fairy tale publication .
i 've noticed writers tend to favor retelling certain stories : little red riding hood , sleeping beauty , cinderella .
these stories seem to speak to people on a subconscious level , each heroine embodying a certain archetype .
what archetype might althea represent ?

guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 3:21pm sam : althea is making her way in the world , and at the beginning of the story does n't know who she is but at the end has some purchase on her experiences .
so the archetype is the young woman who has to go out into the world , and face down all of the obstacles that prevent her from being who she needs to be and can be .
tori : we felt that we wanted teenagers particularly in the 21st century and people who are going to be teenagers and have been , to feel that they are the light princess at times in their day .

i swear to you : i 'm floating every day of my life , somewhere somehow , trying to run away from some confrontation i really do n't want to be involved with , but sometimes in life we have to come down from a beautiful world we 're creating in our mind and have those really tough conversations .

and it might be someone has to have that tough conversation with me , about something i 've said that 's hurt them , or sharing something to become better coworkers , or with family , and that 's something we really wanted to become part of .
a fairly tale that people now can relate to .
the judgement that teenagers face from their peers - it 's always been there , but when i was in high school , it was contained within the high school .
it could travel when there were football games , and the gossip would go from one school to another , but was contained in that way .
and now things can happen at a high school and it 's not contained in that space .

the shaming that can happen to that person is so traumatic that it can change that person 's development and cause so much damage to them , that people are retreating , similar to althea retreating , whether it 's up into your room or somewhere you ca n't be wounded any more - that 's really what we were tapping into .
and we were exposed to the levels of self-harm , because teenagers do n't necessarily feel that people are listening to them and communicating with them .
and it surprised us how much shaming was going on out there .
we were getting so many letters at the stage door of the light princess , people telling us what they were going through .
and now we 're getting messages globally , now the album is out .

and parents , teachers , peers , friends do n't always communicate with kids , teenagers , about trauma , and about loss , they do n't know how to have those conversations so the gulf gets wider and wider .
there 's a wall .
the parents are n't bad people , and the kid is n't a bad person , but they really feel they do n't have a relationship to communicate .
there 's a huge gulf , and real pain .
and that brought us real sadness .
sam : and our story is to some extent about how to bridge that gulf , and the necessity of that resides often with the parents .

we have this character and we spend time with him , and see that he does n't understand his daughter : whether it 's grief , growing pains , whatever it is , he has n't spent time trying to understand her .
and at the time he 's about to lose her , he realises that , and it 's the beginning of the healing of their relationship and redemption for him .

documents.title: 'it 's dangerous to favourite songs , because i think you want to keep your objectivity and bring your best to each one of them '
text: babytiger asks : wow , a tori webchat , good work guardian .
i 've been a fan since silent all these years , and under the pink/boys for pele were a big part of my musical experience at uni .
i used to try to impress the girls by playing your version of smells like teen spirit on the hall piano .
not very well .
question wise do you have a favourite song of your own ?
and is there a song you 've wanted to cover but have n't got around to yet ?

guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 3:09pm it 's dangerous to favourite songs , whether it 's from an album or musical , because i think you want to keep your objectivity and bring your best to each one of them .

for example : in the musical there are 33 songs , almost three albums , and some of them are n't maybe my favourite if you isolate them , but within their function , i value and see them completely differently that when i view them on their own , not interconnected with what comes before and after .
over the years i 've become cautious .
in order to make them really the best they can be , you have to put your personal tastes aside .
not all writers want to write in different genres - some very much write and love writing in a rock or jazz style , and we 're drawn to different forms .

s : it 's one of the reasons i wanted to work with tori becuase she was such an ambitious composer - story could speak to her , and she could find styles and tones and textures that were completely new .
writing a musical , everything is dictated by story .
that 's not to say there ca n't be standout moments of pure emotion , and in fact story is all about emotion .
tori talking about that long sequence queen material , my argument is every single moment was a turning point , and so they demanded music .
she 's a completely different person at the end of the sequence compared with the beginning , and music can show us that in such rich and interesting ways .
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 3:10pm s : tori 's right , it 's invidious to have favourites , and they change according to the day and mood .
but little earthquakes was an incredible piece of work , and my favourite song was clear in your hand .

documents.title: 'i was listening to led zeppelin as a kid , and then i worked with robert in the early 90s . he was a mentor to me he gave me advice on things i did n't even know would happen yet '
text: galena chi mew asks : you 've collaborated with a number of artists from a wide range of genres from the likes of trent reznor to robert plant - who has been your favourite ?

guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:38pm any time you work with another artist its ' really essential not to compare them to somebody else , because sometimes it takes time for them to feel comfortable enough for them to share with you something that you think you 've discovered on their albums by yourself .
you need to understand that sometimes they 're sizing you up .
and sometimes they 're very reserved - i found that with the actors on the light princess .
we had to get to know them , and they had to trust us .

sam : one of the joys of working at the national theatre , and having access to the studio to workshop the light princess , meant we could work with certain actors again and again , and create the story in collaboration .
and design the story to their particular talents .
and that 's reflected in rosalie craig 's performance - it was created for her voice , for her talent as an actor , and for her as a person .
tori : i was listening to led zeppelin as a kid , and then i worked with robert in the early 90s .

to work with somebody you 've grown up listening to is a very different experience to working with a peer - in a way you 're in the same graduating class , you have a different relationship , you learn together .
whereas he was a mentor to me - he gave me advice on things i did n't even know would happen yet .
particularly to do with record labels and how the music business worked , and what to prepare for , and how to protect myself .
that was invaluable .

documents.title: 'you need people who tell you to go away but also to come back '
text: matthew bo asks : what do you think is the cause and solution of this fairly recent phenomenon of outrage addiction people on the internet and media ready , waiting and gleefully jumping on the comments of public figures such as musicians and actors , indignant and offended , demanding apologies or explanations when they do n't correlate with their own views ?

people seem more uptight than ever and ready to twitter-mob with pitchforks waving , policing the words and thoughts of the world , which often ends up in less discourse people scared to say what they really think and believe in case they 're taken down and crucified for it ?
what can we do to restore respect , positive exchange and balance ?
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:55pm sam : i love twitter , i love the connections that you can make , and the social engagement of it .
sometimes as a writer you need to be careful because it can be very time-consuming , and it 's important to avoid looking at too many people 's views of your work , so that can be a pitfall .
i think the conversation is great - where it becomes problematic , is where people post anonymously , and i will always ignore an anonymous comment .
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 3:05pm sam : tori 's an example of an artist , who spends a lot of time looking at the world but not at a computer screen .
i envy her ability to do that .
it 's very easy to be on the guardian website and go from one article to another .
and tori is really great at making sure that does n't happen to her .
tori : it 's discipline and willpower .
and i was warned early on because it does n't matter who these people are , there are musicians who got online and started reading things , and the more they read the less they could write .
this has happened to more than one person .

i found that maybe that was the goal of the people out there , who the musicians were reading : to get them to question themselves so much they became blocked , or something happened so they questioned themselves every time they began working on something .
they allowed these comments in .
s : sometimes you have to protect your ego .
t : and your process .
some people it 's not always criticism in order to make you a better writer , it 's criticism because they do n't have a book deal - sometimes .
there are people i make sure i get feedback from , and we do that , me and sam have people we trust .
but you have to know the intentions of these people , and so i have known artists who have chosen the wrong people .
and it can work the other way too - people who 'll tell you everything is great .
you need people to say : this is n't there yet .
you need people who tell you to go away , but also to come back .

you 'd be surprised how people operate - i 've seen over the years i 'll never forget a musician saying to me , when my record had come out : there are no good records coming out any more , particularly this week .
in those moments you realise , ok , i know what 's going on here , but i am a bit vulnerable this week and i know that , maybe i should n't trust this person in the future .
sometimes those comments can wound , but when people sit there and give you nothing back when people withhold , and do n't give you something to go away and work on .
it 's just cold .
and people do that very well .
pandorafairy asks : i 'd like to know what you think about technology and where it is going .
i used to work in the arts and moved into the it sector .
i 've recently been thinking that i need to go back to the art but am struggling to get the motivation .
my inner voice tells me that the technology boom is another bubble that will burst , and that art is more important .
what do you think ?
do you think that it is an unsustainable industry or that it is stifling our creativity ?
or do you think technology can sometimes be used for good and that we need fairies in technology ?
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:56pm sam : i do n't think art and technology are mutually exclusive things , so they can speak to each other .
tori : i think you need fucking fairies in everything .

documents.title: 'cornwall , once you get out of the cities , you do cross into a strange time you do n't know if you 're in a fairy tale . i do n't know if i could have written the light princess in new york '
text: thewatchingplace asks : i know you did/do sometimes reside in the westcountry i was wondering , as a westcountry native , what is you favourite inspirational ' place in cornwall/devon ?

guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:53pm for me , you want to get off the main roads if you can - go off piste , where there 'll be cows going from one farm to another , one field to another .
and you probably want to get lost , and you 'll be alright .
just do n't drink too much scrumpy .
the cornish have been really good to me .
my studio is there , in an old barn that 's been converted , and we 've been doing all the records there .
sam : we did a lot of the writing there - it 's a beautiful place to write .
tori : it focuses you in cornwall .
sam : it was me , tori and the cows , and that 's brilliant .
there 's a dawn chorus of mooing that wakes you up and makes you want to look at the world and write about it .
tori : cornwall , once you get out of the cities , you do cross into a strange time - what year am i in ?
if you block out makes of cars , and you 're walking the back roads , you do n't know what time you 're in and for a fairytale , that was good for me .
i do n't know if i could have written light princess in new york - it 's a different kind of energy .
s : we 'll have to write another show in new york city , and it 'll be a completely different thing .
monica rien accordi asks : i 'd like to ask you which song has been the most difficult to write and why.also , which is the song you like the most , both in general and among yours ?
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:49pm the most difficult one on light princess was queen material .
sam : i 'm not sure difficult is the right word , but challenging - it 's a sequence , that traverses time and geography .
it 's about the moment when althea escapes the palace she 's been a prisoner , and journeys out into the literal and metaphorical forest and has to encounter certain obstacles .
i said to tori , that i wanted it to be an epic number with huge emotional sweep , but that also propelled the plot and physically took the central character away from everything that she knew .
it runs for about nine minutes on stage , so it took us a long time to write , and we learned a lot in rehearsals - it changed and developed .
tori : you needed sam adamson to tell me what needed to happen my eyes rolled back inside my head .
he continued to speak about the plot , and i 'm still thinking this is the same song sam ?

for me to grasp what was going on - we start in a tower , have a blow-out argument with her father , get around the guards , escape , steal a car , meet an army , run into a dragon and defeat it , get lost and find a lake that is the source for all the water , and realise that she could perhaps be queen material .
sam told me all of this had to be in the song .
and in that moment you have no idea how the two of you are going to achieve that , and the clock 's ticking - you have to be able to write on deadline , that 's the other thing .
bluebluelectricblue asks : first of all thank you so much for your work and for being there for all us ewfs .
you rock my question is : what are some of your favourite films and cinematic influences ?

your songs often conjure great visual images and as a film lover i 've always been curious guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:42pm sam : when i was growing up there were all those great films from the 70s - scorsese , things like that .
as a writer you absorb as much as you can , and it all influences you really .
my favourite scorsese is the age of innocence , a very underrated film .
i love mean streets though too !
tori : right now , tash is torturing me with vikings .
the walking dead - she 's obsessed with mummies no , zombies !
when we 're travelling together i see it on her screen : hannibal .
the eating of people , she thinks it 's quite fantastic .
i 'm being educated .
it 's a very different thing .
i saw the blood eagle thing twice on vikings , because she thought it was so beautiful .

guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:43pm sam : a film i really loved for its insight and cleverness was inside out , which reminded me of the light princess , when the character of joy realises she ca n't live without sadness - that is what the the light princess is all about , the girl in the air has to come down to tackle the complexities in the world , and when she does , she can begin her story .

documents.title: 'as a musician , the most important thing you can do is listen . people think it might be what you 're playing , but that 's actually secondary '
text: matthew bo asks : i 've always appreciated the obscure references and concepts in your songs and albums ( revealing layers upon layers of weaving and genuine poetic art as skill ) which have often resulted in me reading more , researching and broadening my horizons .
what are you reading now ?
and what is the last book you read that sparked joy within you and left you wishing you could share it with the world ?
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:34pm sam : the last book i read was the narrow road to the deep north - an extraordinary novel .
tori : i read robert macfarlane 's the old ways , and john mcphee 's coming into the country .
i 'm listening to how they talk about what they 're discovering in nature .
as a musician , the most important thing you can do is listen .
a lot of people think it might be what you 're playing , but that 's actually secondary .
to hear how these writers were experiencing being out in nature and then turning that into a writing form has been something i 've been looking at for the last few weeks .
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 3:05pm sam : tori 's an example of an artist , who spends a lot of time looking at the world but not at a computer screen .
i envy her ability to do that .
it 's very easy to be on the guardian website and go from one article to another .
and tori is really great at making sure that does n't happen to her .

and i was warned early on because it does n't matter who these people are , there are musicians who got online and started reading things , and the more they read the less they could write .

they allowed these comments in .
s : sometimes you have to protect your ego .

some people it 's not always criticism in order to make you a better writer , it 's criticism because they do n't have a book deal - sometimes .
there are people i make sure i get feedback from , and we do that , me and sam have people we trust .
but you have to know the intentions of these people , and so i have known artists who have chosen the wrong people .
and it can work the other way too - people who 'll tell you everything is great .

it 's just cold .
and people do that very well .

guillaume higgins asks : good day tori and 25 years of respect to you , question 1 ; are you still interested in the art of covers ( slg confirmed you indeed treated this as true art ) and if so , is there songs in the last 5 years that resonates with you enough so you would consider recording them ?

wich leads to question 2 ; considering how b-sides have been a huge part of your output but also how the industry have changed , are you considering new ways to release extra material other than as bonus tracks , as the internet is now an unavoidable step of the music release process that also has its advantages ? question 3 ; it may be argued that the last 7 years of your artistic path has been highly tinged by the light princess , so that midwinter graces , night of hunters and gold dust may be seen as part of that specific cycle , and if so , would you say your next solo record belongs to this cycle , or is in continuity of ug 's style , or will be its own very different thing ?

guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:30pm to q3 : that 's correct that the light princess is in a solar system with midwinter graces and the rest , and they all influence each other , but the light princess is the one constant that 's been brought back .
we were learning something , and changing ; light princess was a driving force for those records .
we were inspired by the orchestra that played on night of hunters , and that is why some of the instruments are similar .

documents.title: 'right now i 'm more interested in original composition for theatre or film . we 're looking at the possibilities of the light princess as a film '
text: sarah elizabeth hirsch asks : after so many unique albums which all have their own sound and when you find inspiration for a new girl ( which you ca n't possible part with ) is she the one that sets the tone for the album ?
or do you wait for other inspiration to set a tone ?
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:27pm well , right now i 'm more interested in original composition for the theatre or film .
the idea of a jukebox musical is something at present that i would most likely avoid .

mainly because i 'm much more drawn to the possibility of creating something new , whether that 's an adaptation of an existing story , like the light princess , or coming up with something completely new .
we 're looking at the possibilities of the light princess as a film
aidansalander asks : i 've recently become a fan of yours and it is truly thrilling to explore your interesting body of work .
i have hopes of becoming a musician myself , but i fear that because i 'm 22 it may be too late to start .
that , and i can only just about play guitar , sing and i can not play the piano .
however i have a very vivid imagination and ideas that i 'm dying to communicate with people .
my main avenue of expression is through my writing and have only recently started to write lyrics .
what advice can you give to me ?
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:24pm s : that 's very young to start writing .
keep at it , never give up .
share your work with people you trust .
consider their good ideas and reject their bad ideas .
t : and be kind to yourself about it .
music is a language , you 're going to be learning a language - maybe later than some people , but that does n't mean that you ca n't become proficient in it .
discipline is always a friend .
s : yes - work hard .
and rewrite , craft .
sometimes lyric writing can be quite a contained form , but the paradox is that that containment can be very liberating when you land on the right word choice or whatever it is .
thomas carron asks : hello tori !
i 'm 19 and i fell in love with your music just a few years ago .
i was wondering if you could tell me where your inspirations came from for the score for the light princess ?
did you take inspiration from other musicals ?
i 've noticed a lot of elements incorporated into the new release are similar to that of night of hunters .
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:21pm tori : it was clear from early workshops that it was n't going to be pop-rock , a rock-band driven musical .
we talked about making a choice that the instrumentation would be more orchestral , with a piano involved .
there are not a lot of pianos in musical scores .
sam : sometimes you do n't hear the piano if it exists , sometimes it 's not there at all , sometimes it 's a synthesiser .
one of the things i love about the original cast recording is that tori 's piano work is more central , it becomes a central character .
it often reflects altea 's joy and happiness in moments of arpeggios and runs .
tori : we listened to so many musicals : cabaret for me anyway .
a little night music .
jesus christ superstar .
s : when you 're working in the form you need to immerse yourself in what other writers have done .
t : there are so many amazing ones , in unique styles - if anyone says there are n't any , they have n't done their homework .
it might not be to your personal taste , but as a songwriter , you have to look beyond that .
you have to listen from a place of neutrality and see when songs are working and why they 're working even if the style is n't necessarily your favourite .
s : we 're both obsessed with how song dictates story , and the light princess is nearly through-sung - it 's almost operatic sometimes .

documents.title: 'for a collaboration , work with a team that you trust . and that inspires you , and you want to take a long trek up a musical himalayan mountain with . and if there is a no to any of these questions , then you need to run for the hills really quickly '
text: hollyhavers asks : very appreciative of the opportunities you 're giving fans in asking you questions via more q & a web chat interviews like this .
thank you .
congratulations on the light princess ocr release .
hearing the result of such a long and undoubtedly arduous project is a joy .
the music is spectacular , and for fans who were n't able to see the musical during its run , the ocr is especially a treat .
how did you find working on a project that required such a high level of collaboration ?
what were the major challenges , and how did you work through them ?
what was it about george macdonald 's tale that grabbed you and inspired you to take your idea to the national theatre ?
were there others you were considering at the time ?
after taking this magnificent project from the seed of an idea to completion , what are some of the most important things you learned on the way through ?
did you have times where you wanted to give up ?
how did you get through those times ?
i read that you hope the light princess is n't the only musical you 'll write in your career .
is this a direction you see your career moving in ?
is there anything you can reveal at the moment about your next steps ?
thanks so much for continuing to produce such wonderful work , and for all you 've done throughout the years .
you 're still my # 1 inspiration .
guardian contributor toriamos1 26 october 2015 2:15pm tori and sam here - answering this question together .
we 're busking .
sam : regarding what grabbed us , the tale has a very original and beautiful and simple central idea : this girl floats until she learns what it is to love , and lose love .
and once she understands those things , she cries and comes to the ground for the first time in her life .
it felt to us that we could find contemporary resonance in that simple idea if we really asked questions about who the girl was and why she was in the air .
tori : the major challenges of collaboration would be making sure you 're working with a team that you trust .
and that obviously inspires you , and that you want to take a long trek up a musical himalayan mountain with .
and if there is a no to any of these questions , then you need to run for the hills really quickly .

sam and i would spend a lot of time talking through things , and songs came in different ways : people have asked us if we had a routine in writing a song , it 's different how they would come about .

sam : everything was story led so story would dictate the direction of music and lyrics , but just by being together we would spend lots of time talking about the characters and scoring and plot , and sometimes we 'd have to throw those things out .
tori : there were a lot of songs we really liked as songs , but realised : this is n't the moment for it .
sam : songs would change a lot , and reimagine themselves .
a glorious challenge was getting to know each other , understanding each other as people , and not being frightened of each other , and respecting each other 's processes .
i never had times i wanted to give up though .

documents.title: post your questions for tori amos
text: tori amos was two and a half when she first placed her fingers on the keys of a piano .
her immediate , instinctive skill with the instrument led to her admission into the peabody conservatory for music in baltimore aged just five .
but she was kicked out six years later for wanting to do my own thing .

it is perhaps that organic , untamed and unique approach to creating music that first established amos alongside the likes of bjã¶rk and pj harvey , as part of an innovative new wave of vocalists , and led to the success of her 13 records , totalling in 12m album sales and eight grammy nominations .

while her single cornflake girl became one of the definitive tracks of the 1990s , the virtuoso pianist was an anomaly in the mainstream pop world an outsider artist who wrote songs about femininity in all its brutal , beautiful and bare-boned glory .
now , 25 years on from her debut album , little earthquakes , amos releases the soundtrack to her first stage production , the light princess .
the score to the musical , loosely based on george macdonald 's 19th-century fairytale and adapted by playwright samuel adamson , was created by the songwriter and released on 9 october .
amos along with adamson will join us for a live webchat to answer your questions , from 2pm onwards on monday 26 october .
she 'll be taking questions about anything , not just the new release , so post yours in the comments below , and she 'll take on as many as possible .
